WELCOME

Welcome to Peerio Icebear SDK documentation.

HTML version of this documentation contains all documented members.

  • lock icon denotes member private to parent module, it's not exported from module.
  • cogs icon denotes protected member for SDK internal use, it's exported from module, but is not exported from index
  • question icon denotes unspecified access level (should be fixed)

Markdown version contains only items marked as @public and is not as well organized as HTML version, sort order is different.

Configuration

Icebear exports configuration object that you have to initialize with some mandatory properties and configure some optional ones.

The recommended pattern to deal with configuration:

  1. Create config.js in source root of your project
    // import icebear config
    const config = require('icebear').config;

    // set and override properties
    config.icebearProperty = 'value';
    config.clientSpecificProperty = 'value'

    // and export extended config object in the end
    module.exports = config;
  1. Require this config.js at your app startup so it extends Icebear config.

config

src/config.js

Configuration module. Exists just to collect most of the app configuration aspects in one place.

Following properties have to be set before client app starts using Icebear SDK. Best to do it in your local config.js

  • socketServerUrl
  • ghostFrontendUrl
  • appVersion
  • platform
  • FileStream
  • StorageEngine
config
Static Members
▸ upload.chunkSizes
src/config.js

For reference. Table of chunk sizes based on file sizes. Is not supposed to be changed ever. If you do change it for some reason - remember to restart paused uploads as file chunk size might change.

upload.chunkSizes

Type: Array<{maxFileSize: number?, chunkSize: number}>

▸ upload.getChunkSize(fileSize)
src/config.js

Finds which chunk size to use for given file size based on chunkSizes reference table.

upload.getChunkSize(fileSize: number): number
Parameters
fileSize (number) in bytes.
Returns
number : chunk size to use, in bytes.
▸ upload.encryptBufferSize
src/config.js

Max amount of bytes to buffer from disk for encrypting. This number can't be less than maximum chunk size.

upload.encryptBufferSize

Type: number

▸ upload.uploadBufferSize
src/config.js

Max amount of chunks to pre-encrypt for sending This number can't be less than maximum chunk size.

upload.uploadBufferSize

Type: number

▸ upload.uploadBufferSize
src/config.js

Max amount of uploaded chunks per one file waiting for server response. When reached this number, uploader will wait for at least one chunk to get a response. Bigger number = faster upload = more pressure on server. 0-5 is a reasonable range to pick. Default is 2.

upload.uploadBufferSize

Type: number

▸ debug.trafficReportInterval
src/config.js

Traffic stat summary will be logged with this interval (ms.)

debug.trafficReportInterval

Type: number

▸ debug.socketLogEnabled
src/config.js

All socket messages will be logged if set to true before socket is started.

debug.socketLogEnabled

Type: boolean

▸ socketServerUrl
src/config.js

App server connection url. (wss://)

Client app is required to set this property before using Icebear SDK.

socketServerUrl

Type: string

▸ ghostFrontendUrl
src/config.js

Ghost website url. (https://)

Client app is required to set this property before using Icebear SDK.

ghostFrontendUrl

Type: string

▸ appVersion
src/config.js

Application version (semver). Will be used by server to detect deprecated client versions.

Client app is required to set this property before using Icebear SDK.

appVersion

Type: string

▸ platform
src/config.js

Strictly one of: 'electron', 'outlook', 'android', 'ios', 'browser', unless server has been updated to support more platform strings and this documentation wasn't :-P

Client app is required to set this property before using Icebear SDK.

platform

Type: string

▸ CHUNK_OVERHEAD
src/config.js

For reference. Amount of bytes added to every file chunk in encrypted state. DO NOT change this value unless you really know what you're doing.

CHUNK_OVERHEAD
Returns
number : 32
▸ download.maxDownloadChunkSize
src/config.js

Max amount of bytes to download at once for further processing. File gets downloaded in 'downloadChunks' and then broken down to the chunk size it was uploaded with. This number can't be less than maximum chunk size.

download.maxDownloadChunkSize

Type: number

▸ download.maxDecryptBufferSize
src/config.js

Max amount of bytes to download and queue for decryption. This number can't be less than maximum chunk size.

download.maxDecryptBufferSize

Type: number

▸ FileStream
src/config.js

File stream implementation class.

Client app is required to set this property before using Icebear SDK.

FileStream

Type: FileStreamAbstract

▸ StorageEngine
src/config.js

Storage engine implementation class.

Client app is required to set this property before using Icebear SDK.

StorageEngine

Type: StorageEngineInterface

▸ observableClockEventFrequency
src/config.js

Frequency (seconds) at which default observable clock will be changing its value. Default clock can be used for refreshing timestamps and other time counters. Do not set this value too low, create custom clocks instead.

observableClockEventFrequency

Type: number

▸ chat.maxInitialChats
src/config.js

Maximum amount of chats to load initially. Favorite chats will ignore this and load in full number.

chat.maxInitialChats

Type: number

▸ chat.initialPageSize
src/config.js

Amount of messages to load to a chat initially.

chat.initialPageSize

Type: number

▸ chat.pageSize
src/config.js

When navigating chat history, load this amount of messages per page.

chat.pageSize

Type: number

▸ chat.maxLoadedMessages
src/config.js

Icebear will unload messages over this limit, resulting is low memory consumption when navigating history or chatting normally.

chat.maxLoadedMessages

Type: number

▸ chat.decryptQueueThrottle
src/config.js

Delay (ms) between decryption of individual messages when processing a batch. Increase to get more responsiveness, but increase page load time.

chat.decryptQueueThrottle

Type: number

Entry point

To use Icebear SDK you need to require its entry point at any time you need it. Icebear will initialize whatever needs to be initialized, you just have to start the socket connection once, whenever your application is ready.

const icebear = require('icebear');
icebear.socket.start();

Entry point exports all the public API you will need.

index

src/index.js

In addition to exporting public API, entry point, when first required, performs some global configuration such as:

  • replaces global Promise object with bluebird implementation. Note that native(not transpiled) async functions will still return native Promise.
  • extends Uint8Array prototype. See extensions/uint8array.
index

Static Members
▸ slice(begin, end)
src/extensions/uint8array.js

Returns a new Uint8Array containing a portion of current array defined by parameters.

slice(begin: number, end: number): Uint8Array

Extends Uint8Array

Parameters
begin (number = 0 ) starting index in the original array. Can be negative to mark position counting from the end the array.
end (number = this.length ) ending index (exclusive) in the original array. Can be negative to mark position counting from the end the array.
Returns
Uint8Array : new array containing a range of bytes from original array.

errors

src/errors.js

Peerio custom error types and error handling helpers.

// CUSTOM ERROR TEMPLATE
function CustomError(message, nestedError, otherData) {
  var error = Error.call(this, message);
  this.name = 'CustomError';
  this.message = error.message;
  this.stack = error.stack;
  this.nestedError = nestedError;
  this.otherData = otherData;
}

CustomError.prototype = Object.create(Error.prototype);
CustomError.prototype.constructor = CustomError;
errors
Static Members
▸ normalize(error, failoverMessage?)
src/errors.js

Use this helper to resolve returning error value. If you:

  • have an error result from catch() or reject()
  • don't know what exactly that result is, Error, string, undefined or something else
  • don't need custom errors just want to generate meaningful Error object

Call normalize and pass the result you've got together with fallback message, that will be wrapped in Error object and returned in case the result wasn't instance of Error

normalize(error: any, failoverMessage: string?): Error
Parameters
error (any) anything you received as an error via catch
failoverMessage (string?) if error will not be of Error instance, this message wrapped in new Error object will be returned
Returns
Error :
▸ getGenericCustomError(name, msg)
src/errors.js

Helper function to create custom errors with less code. It's useful when your custom error only expects to have an optional message and data object arguments.

getGenericCustomError(name: string, msg: string): function
Parameters
name (string) custom error name, should match the class name you will use for the error
msg (string) default message for the error
Returns
function : class, inherited from Error

src/errors.js

Check sources for the list of codes. You can look up this enum both by integer code and by string error name.

serverErrorCodes

▸ formatBytes(bytes)
src/util.js

Converts bytes number to human-readable string format.

formatBytes(bytes: number): string
Parameters
bytes (number)
Returns
string : formatted string.
Example
formatBytes(1024); // returns '1 KB'

crypto

Crypto modules export publicly everything they have for internal icebear use. Normally you don't need to use it because Icebear handles all the encryption/keys/signing on its own. But in case your application requires some special logic you have the full crypto toolkit for it.

crypto/util

src/crypto/util.js

Peerio crypto utilities module. Exported from icebear index as crypto.cryptoUtil

▸ getRandomNumber(min, max)
src/crypto/util.random.js

Generated cryptographically secure random number in a set range. Range can't be more then 2**31 (2147483648).

getRandomNumber(min: number, max: number): number
Parameters
min (number = 0 ) minimum random number value (inclusive)
max (number = 2147483648 ) maximum random value (exclusive)
Returns
number : random number
Throws
  • InvalidArgumentError:
▸ getRandomNonce()
src/crypto/util.random.js

Generates 24-byte unique random nonce. Partially consists of 4 bytes of current timestamp. 4 bytes fits almost 50 days worth of milliseconds, so if you are generating 1 nonce every millisecond, it's guaranteed to have no collisions within 50 days even without random bytes part.

getRandomNonce(): Uint8Array
Returns
Uint8Array : 24 bytes, 4: from timestamp
▸ getRandomUserSpecificIdBytes(username)
src/crypto/util.random.js

Generates random id bytes. Partially consists of hashed username and timestamp.

getRandomUserSpecificIdBytes(username: string): Uint8Array
Parameters
username (string)
Returns
Uint8Array : 42 bytes, 16: username+timestamp hash

crypto/secret

src/crypto/secret.js

Secret key encryption module.

Encrypt and decrypt functions replace nacl.secretbox and nacl.secretbox.open see tweetnacl-js https://github.com/dchest/tweetnacl-js. This replacement reduces the amount of memory allocation and copy operations.

The output cipher bytes have following differences with nacl.secretbox output:

  • nonce is appended to the cipher bytes.
  • 16 BOXZEROBYTES in the beginning of cipher bytes are not stripped and another 16 are appended to them because we'll need them for decryption

Cipherbytes structure: [ 32 zero bytes ][ actual cipher bytes ][ 24-byte nonce]

crypto/secret
Static Members
▸ NONCE_SIZE
src/crypto/secret.js

24 - The size of the nonce is used for encryption

NONCE_SIZE

Type: number

▸ encrypt(msgBytes, key, nonce, appendNonce, prependLength)
src/crypto/secret.js

Encrypts and authenticates data using symmetric encryption. This is a refactored version of nacl.secretbox().

encrypt(msgBytes: Uint8Array, key: Uint8Array, nonce: Uint8Array, appendNonce: boolean, prependLength: boolean): Uint8Array
Parameters
msgBytes (Uint8Array)
key (Uint8Array) 32 bytes symmetric key
nonce (Uint8Array = getRandomNonce() ) in case you want to set your own nonce. 24 bytes.
appendNonce (boolean = true ) appends nonce to the end of encrypted bytes
prependLength (boolean = false ) adds 4 bytes containing message length after encryption to the beginning
Returns
Uint8Array : encrypted bytes
▸ encryptString(msg, key)

▸ decrypt(cipher, key, nonce, containsLength)
src/crypto/secret.js

Decrypts and authenticates data using symmetric encryption. This is a refactored version of nacl.secretbox.open().

decrypt(cipher: Uint8Array, key: Uint8Array, nonce: Uint8Array, containsLength: boolean): Uint8Array
Parameters
cipher (Uint8Array) cipher bytes with 16 zerobytes prepended and optionally appended nonce
key (Uint8Array) 32 bytes symmetric key
nonce (Uint8Array = 'will be extracted from message' ) pass nonce when it's not appended to cipher bytes
containsLength (boolean = false ) whether or not to ignore first 4 bytes
Returns
Uint8Array : decrypted message

TinyDb

src/db/tiny-db.js

Local storage for small amounts of data like user preferences and flags.

new TinyDb(name: string, encryptionKey: Uint8Array?)
Parameters
name (string) database name
encryptionKey (Uint8Array?) encryption key
Example
// at any time use unencrypted shared database
TinyDb.system.getValue('lastAuthenticatedUsername');
// after successful login use User's personal encrypted database.
// Only values are encrypted.
TinyDb.user.setValue('lastUsedEmoji',':grumpy_cat:')

socket

src/helpers/validation/user-validators.js

Validation functions for user-related fields, used in field validation.

On peerio-desktop they are used in conuction with the ValidatedInput and OrderedFormStore components. ValidatedInputs expect validators of the format below as parameters, and will run through them on change & blur as needed.

Validators are (arrays of) objects, with signature: { action: 'function', message: '' }

The action function accepts arguments:

  • value -- usually a string

  • additionalArguments -- optional object

    It returns true if the value passes validation. Otherwise it may return an object with the signature:

    { message: 'optional specific validation message (string)', result: false // additional data as needed }

    if the function does not return a message, the default message provided by the validator will be used.

ChatKegDb

src/models/kegs/chat-keg-db.js

Chat loading logic retryUntilSuccess( 1. Do we have ID for the chat?

  • 1.1 NO:

    • create-chat
    • if resolved: now we have chat meta data, GOTO (2.)
    • if rejected: retry is triggered

  • 1.2 YES:

    • get metadata
    • if resolved: now we have chat meta data, GOTO (2.)
    • if rejected: retry is triggered
  1. Parse chat metadata
  2. Does boot keg exist? (load it and check if keg version > 1)

  • 3.1 YES:

    • load boot keg

    • resolved: is it valid ?

      • YES: FINISH. Promise.resolve(true)
      • NO: FINISH. Promise.resolve(false) for retry to not trigger
    • rejected: retry is triggered

  • 3.2 NO:

    • create boot keg.

      • resolved: FINISH. Promise.resolve(true)
      • rejected: retry is triggered
  • 3.3 load failed: retry is triggered , 'Unique retry id')
new ChatKegDb(id: any, participants: any)

participants (any)

save

src/models/kegs/synced-keg.js

Enqueues Save task.

save(dataChangeFn: function<bool>, dataRestoreFn: function?, errorLocaleKey: string?): Promise
Parameters
dataChangeFn (function<bool>) function that will be called right before keg save, it has to mutate keg's state. Return false to cancel save.
dataRestoreFn (function?) function that will be called to restore keg state to the point before dataChangeFn mutated it. Default implementation will rely on keg serialization functions. dataRestoreFn will only get called if version of the keg didn't change after save failed. This will make sure we won't overwrite freshly received data from server.
errorLocaleKey (string?) optional error to show in snackbar
Returns
Promise :

▸ _derivePassphraseFromPasscode(passcodeSecret)
src/models/user/user.auth.js

Derive a passphrase and set it for future authentications (only called if applicable on first login). Won't throw if the passcode is incorrect -- login will proceed treating the same user input as a passphrase instead of a passcode, allowing users who have a passcode set to still use their passphrases.
